comments.commentBody: It is wrong to blame "the left", as there has been almost no true left in U.S. politics since the anti-Communist government terror began about 90 years ago.  The New Deal was a brief interruption in the process of demonizing pro-worker proposals like those mentioned in the article.  The government (and media) terror campaign led most prominent liberals to become more vocal about anti-Communism, including opposition to anything called "socialistic", than about defending the working people of America.  The "left" you refer to is the center in the spectrum of politics of developed countries, and it has been terrorized and co-opted by the (increasingly extreme) right for longer than the entire lifetime of almost everyone alive in this country.
An excellent, superb analysis!

The path to our police state was an interesting one, and was well under way before 9/11. Once private internet companies realized what they had, it was only a matter of time until people in the government had to have it.

It then became a case of desk jockeys longing to follow their secret intelligence fantasies as far as they could take them. At one time, these types were minor staffers or quants, kept from making key decisions.

That kind of power doesn't just corrupt, it destroys, on both sides. Control the information and there are many possibilities. Odd people start to sweat with excitement once they learn they have first peek at everyone's personal details. Since spooks are not stable people, they should be the last ones to know our intimate stories.

All of this is not new, since totalitarian governments all furiously collect information as a way to control its flow. Then, the people can be herded into the correct points of view. Included in this pattern are demonization of the poor, the foreign, and the helpless.

We have let this happen, through passivity and fear. Time to come up with a new plan.

If Federal support to the University of Washington were directly linked to first-year salaries of graduates, as some have proposes, you can be sure that the excellent programs you describe would quickly be eliminated in the name of self preservation.

If you manage to metrics, those metrics have to be comprehensive, otherwise you destroy the whole rest of the enterprise in favor of the measured activity that is supposed to serve as a proxy for the rest.

Ruralist hits the nail on the head. Colleges and universities already spend a lot of time and energy trying to manipulate their US News & World Report ranking. The proposed "value" ranking will provide a clear incentive for them to adjust their admission criteria to improve their ranking. The ideal candidate is a prep school grad from a wealthy family who states that they want to major in business. An applicant who is the first in their family to apply to college, who went to a mediocre high school, who is poor, and who states that they want to major in social work is a nightmare candidate as far as their contribution to the college's score.

And once the chosen students matriculate, you can be sure that there will be pressures applied in subtle and not-so-subtle ways to steer them into the higher-earning majors.

The top schools won't suffer much - the UW and a handful of other top flagship public schools (and of course elite private schools) already have a good enough reputation that they don't need to worry about gaming the scoring system too much. But the temptation for the next tier of schools to move up the scoring list will result in subtle and not-so-subtle changes to their admissions.

The one good outcome would be if the scores helped to put sketchy for-profit schools out of business.

While your shilling for UW is likely heartfelt, it is also irrelevant to the majority of large public institutions today. UW has a $2 billion endowment, many times what similar schools have. They also have state support which greatly exceeds a large number of public schools.

If your argument is really that public universities can be great given sustained and adequate public funding, I would concur. But that is not what you said.

how's this for a metric:

(Total available money per student) vs (outcome)

Well endowed schools, which have perhaps $200,000 per student per year, against those with less than 1/10th as much. Let's see how they compare.

"Ratings based on graduation rates will encourage them to admit fewer students who might be less prepared for college, who graduate in lower numbers."

This is a phony argument.

The University of Washington provides free tuition to resident students based on family income, some 8,500 in 2012, a major factor in a overall graduation rate of 80%. The UW provides alternative acceptance through state community colleges, which allows students to overcome poor earlier educational experiences.

The UW also has more than 100 degree programs ranked in the top 10 in the US, so educational quality and graduate earning does not suffer by providing opportunity to low income students.

And UW is typical of many great state universities providing excellent educational value today.

Performance transparency will hurt diploma mills that generate lots of student debt and little employment opportunity and that is the point.

And there will never be a shortage of parents willing to spend $50,000 or more a year to send their kid to an elite private college.

Do you feel that Snowden should be granted a Presidential pardon for cheating on the exam to obtain employment as a contractor for the NSA in Hawaii with the specific intent of mining data that he should not have had access to in the first place? Maybe you feel that Snowden should be pardoned for absconding to Hong Kong with his stolen files - do you find his fleeing the country of his own accord particularly heroic, proper, or necessary? Or, should he receive a pardon for then making that intelligence available to people who have profited by the purloined intelligence by publishing it for all the world to see, jeopardizing America's security and causing a strain on foreign relations?

Snowden carefully planned his mission, he didn't simply come upon the "leaked files" through his work in Hawaii - he has admitted to taking the job with Booz Allen specifically to obtain the files he stole. He was so much more than a whistleblower - he broke into and entered areas of the NSA he had no legal access to, and he download millions of files. Imagine anyone working in private business doing such a thing, let alone someone who took an oath of secrecy.

How exactly has "Mr. Snowden... done more to advance the cause of freedom in the US and around the world"? We are all being watched whenever we use our computers, cell phones, debit cards - it's the digital age, my friend, and the US government's surveillance of you should be the least of your worries.

For those that think it is only about guns, and mentioning other factors are just diversionary tactic, consider this. The 50 largest metropolitan areas (MSAs) in the US have 54% of the population, but 67 percent of all gun homicides. But the cities contained inside of these MSAs almost all have even higher rates of gun homicides. For the US as a whole, the gun homicide rate is 4.2 (per hundred thousand population). For the largest MSAs, it is 5.2, and for the cities within those MSAs, it averages 9.7. For many of these areas the differences are even more extreme, such as Sacramento, where the MSAS has a rate of 3.6, while the city rate is 11.1, or The New York MSA with a rate of 3.2, and Newark with a rate of 25.4. For the population excluding theses MSAs, it averages somewhere close to 2.5. The geographic disparities for youth gun violence are even greater.

The right wing extremist group, the CDC, thinks that we should use this data to focus our anti gun violence efforts:

"National and state prevention programs directed at reducing firearm violence should focus on youths, particularly in central cities, to reduce the burden of firearm-related mortality in the United States. Initiatives designed to reduce violent deaths in urban areas can draw upon a growing evidence base for effectively addressing behaviors that underlie violence involving youths."

http://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/pdf/wk/mm6018.pdf

'Try working part time at WalMart for awhile and then tell me that the NSA is your biggest problem.' ~ paul, CA

I sympathise. Nevertheless, if you are a resident of a US town where there's a Walmart or some such, you can choose whether or not to work for Wal-Mart Stores Inc or for some other exploitative US employer. If you don't like it, then you can improve your qualifications or skills, move to another town or even another country. That's always been the American way.

No one, however, US citizen or non-citizen, resident or non-resident in the USA, has any direct say whatsoever in what the US National Security Agency decides to do to you. Even the so-called 'courts' that oversee the NSA admit no litigant to the proceedings.

To take up your challenge, therefore, with the exception of those who live in North Korea and similar jurisdictions, I say yes - the NSA *is* everyone's biggest problem.
